div1.p: Consulat General Of the Independent State of the Congo. Baltimore.

Seen that the debates on the subject of the annexation Vu que will take place very soon in the Belgium Parlement and seen that our enemies will seize this opportunity to exploit all the socialist rhetoirc, I'd like to take the opportunity to bring to your attention the importance of telegraphing, by the agencies of the press, about the summary of the speeches about the des consevateurs et des annexionistes, in order to give the American public a just impression of Belgian opinion.
At present we are recieving in America a lot of telegraphes inspired by socialiste speech and we hear nothing of talk from the King's defenders.

You will find herewith some telegraphes to about the respect of Mr. Vandervelde and Mr. Bertrand's speech, but I cannot find in any journal the slightest mention of the important speech made by Mr. Schollaert.
The state of things seems to be the fault of the press offices in Brussels, London, and Paris, who are, without a doubt, somewhat under the influence of our enemies.

What I propose, Sir Knight, est to look to change all of this, to win the sympathies of the press agencies, and in this way to send, every now and then, during the debates, the following telegraphs of favorable speeches made by the Congo Administration.

I know that the program that I am coming to propose to you is somewhat difficult and I cannot promise a full vicotry, but I am convinced that on can almst soften the opinions from the press offices, and by this way, that one could, make a favorable impression to the public
